results.title: The Wodaabe
results.creator_credit: Leslie Woodhead and Granada Television International
results.brief_description:
Episode number 1 of Series “Disappearing world”.
The Wodaabe are among the world’s last true nomads. They follow their herds in an endless migration across African borders. They have no houses, no huts and no tents. They live and sleep under the skies. Although droughts have ravaged their lands since the 1960’s, anthropologist Mette Bovin sees their life as a balance between hardship and joy. They have an obsession with male beauty and Wodaabe men wear more make-up than Wodaabe women. “We like to see people who are handsome” says one. The Wodaabe insist they will remain nomads despite mounting pressures for them to settle down and lead a “normal” life.

results.title: Some people have to suffer
results.creator_credit: Christopher Pinney and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: This film documents a community’s struggle to survive in the face of government indifference and the political and financial clout of industrial developers. In 1953 the residents of Bridgeview, British Columbia, were promised sewers; following years of debate, frustration, meetings and verbiage, construction started in 1977. The film interviews some of the residents, who state their opinions frankly both to the camera and at meetings. When the film was shown at the Habitat conference in Vancouver, 1976, press coverage noted: “The Third World is merely twenty miles from the site of Habitat.” Narration: Boyce Richardson.

results.title: Song & dance = Song and dance
results.creator_credit: Tom Gutteridge, Cameron Mackintosh and Really Useful Films
results.brief_description: This presentation of Andrew Lloyd Webber’s Song and Dance was recorded live for television at the Palace Theatre, London. It is a musical in two acts with the first act “Song - Tell me on a Sunday” featuring the beautiful voice of Sarah Brightman in the role of Emma, and the second act “Dance - Variations” starring dancer Wayne Sleep in the role of Joe. Lyrics by Don Black, choreography by Anthony Van Laast and musical direction by David Caddick.

results.title: Some call it progress (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: Tina Viljoen, Barrie Howells and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: The problems of inner city redevelopment. Change has become the hallmark of older cities, as old buildings are demolished to make way for the new high-rise edifices of today’s developers. However many citizens are appalled by the change and have formed Citizens Actions Groups to let the administrative officers know of their opposition. Details of some action groups are shown in Sydney, Montreal and Brussels

results.title: Masai manhood
results.creator_credit: Chris Curling and Granada Television International
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Disappearing world”.
Shows the process of attaining maturity for men in the Masai tribes. Starting in the late teens the young men serve seven years as ‘Moran’ or warriors. The end of their adolescence is celebrated at a spectacular ceremony- ‘Eunoto’ - which formally prepares the Moran to take their place as mature members of the tribe.

results.title: Kataragama: a god for all seasons
results.creator_credit: Charlie Nairn and Granada Television International
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Disappearing world”.
The story of how the parents of an eleven-year old Sri Lankan boy consulted an astrologer to help them find their son. The astrologer instructs them to seek help from the god, Kataragama, who correctly forecast the boy would be returned in twenty one days. Shows scenes of worshippers of Kataragama who thank him for favours received by walking through pits of red hot fire. Some hung themselves from butcher’s hooks impaled in their backs.

results.title: Somazone (MAC & PC)
results.creator_credit: Richard Jones, Tom Olsson, Cinemedia, Electric Alchemy, Human Services, Legal Aid Commission of Victoria, National Asthma Campaign and Quit
results.brief_description: SomaZone is about exploring, experimenting and making choices. It’s a “Life-Simulator” which gives teenagers a chance for real decision-making. By creating a “personal body”, users can take risks and see what happens. SomaZone is a multimedia package designed to look at health, society and the law from the perspective of adolescents. Discussion notes are included in the CD in WORD format. Technical requirements: Will run on PC and MAC. PC’s need Windows 3.1 or later; 486 - 66 CPU; 6MB of free RAM; 2 x CD-ROM drive; SVGA (256 colours); 16 bit Soundblaster or compatible; Quicktime for Windows 2.1.2 (supplied). Macintosh: System 7 or later; 030 - 30MHz; 6 MB of free Ram; 2 x CD-ROM drive; 256 colours; Quicktime 2.5 supplied.

results.title: Solving linear equations with one variable
results.creator_credit: Mark M Williams, Bill Hanlon and KLVX (Television station : Las Vegas, Nev.)
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Algebra, you can do it”.
This program introduces solving linear equations with one variable when the variable is a natural number. Students will be shown basic rules that will allow them to solve this type of equation. Suitable for lower to middle secondary level students. A guide accompanies this video.

results.title: Solomon Islands
results.creator_credit: Denmark, Leif Stubkjaer, and U-V Film and Video
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Oceans of Dreams - Currents of Change Series”.
This film examines the rich traditional and village life which continues alongside the adaption to modern ways. The Solomon Islands are a place of extreme contrasts even as the tides of change gradually affect these islands.
